properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, and significant snowmelt is expected. Total rainfall: 25 to 40 mm, except possibly exceeding 50 mm over higher elevations. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: tonight until Tuesday night. Remarks: A prolonged rainfall event is expected in conjunction with very mild temperatures. Rain will be heaviest over higher elevations, resulting in large amounts of snowmelt and runoff. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-10T00:38:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-09T08:39:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2215795581.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and strong winds are expected. Total rainfall: 30 mm with higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 80 km/h. Stronger coastal gusts possible. Locations: Connaigre Peninsula. Time span: Tuesday and Tuesday evening. Remarks: Showers will change to rain Tuesday morning. Rainfall amounts may reach warning criteria by Tuesday evening and a rainfall warning may be required with subsequent forecasts. Strong southwesterly winds gusting to 80 km/h will develop near noon on Tuesday. The potential exists for stronger wind gusts along coastal areas. A wind warning may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-10T00:41:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-09T08:42:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1719933813.2019
Area: Connaigre
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The North Bay area will be very close to the boundary between mild air, currently over the region, and much colder air with freezing rain and snow just a short distance to the northwest. Freezing rain warnings remain in effect for areas as close as Sudbury and Temagami. Rain from a Colorado low is expected to arrive this morning and with the track of the low expected to be directly over the region, temperatures are expected to remain just above the zero degree mark through the day. As the low moves by tonight, much colder air from the northwest will move in, causing temperatures to plummet to well below freezing resulting in a quick changeover to snow. A flash freeze warning may be issued later today as a result. If the low tracks even a little further south than currently expected, the cold air could arrive sooner resulting in a threat of freezing rain today. Motorists should be prepared for poor winter driving conditions tonight as much colder air arrives and temperatures plunge to well below freezing. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-10T02:13:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-09T10:14:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3614084513.2019
Area: North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain likely Monday. Precipitation associated with an approaching Colorado Low will move into portions of northeastern Ontario Monday morning or early afternoon. Several hours of freezing rain are possible in some areas from Monday afternoon into the evening. At this point, the greatest threat of freezing rain will likely be from just south of Elliot Lake towards Sudbury and areas north of the city of North Bay, where freezing rain warnings have already been issued. Freezing rain warnings may be expanded to other areas if required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T17:40:08-00:00

Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong westerly winds will reduce visibilities to near zero today. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow causing widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain this afternoon and evening. Precipitation associated with an approaching Colorado Low will move into northeastern Ontario beginning later this morning. Although there will be a patchy freezing drizzle in the morning, the more significant threat of freezing rain will be in the afternoon and early evening. Several hours of freezing rain are likely in some areas. Several millimetres of ice accretion are possible with some areas likely receiving several centimetres of snow in addition to the freezing rain. Freezing rain will change to all snow towards midnight as much colder air arrives in from the north in the wake of the low. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-10T02:17:36-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A messy mix of precipitation on tap today. The Sault Ste. Marie area will be very close to the rain - snow line as a Colorado low passes by just to the south of the area later today. As a result, much of the precipitation will fall as snow and ice pellets, with some rain possible especially over St. Joseph Island. Freezing rain is also possible, although the greatest threat appears to be just to the east of the area where freezing rain warnings are in effect. Precipitation will change over to all snow by midnight as much colder air arrives from the north in the wake of the low. Total snowfall amounts of 4 to 8 centimetres are expected by the time the snow ends tonight. A slight change in the track of the low will affect how much snow, rain or freezing rain falls at a particular location. Poor winter driving conditions are expected. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-10T02:06:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-09T10:07:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3119225646.2019
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island

properties.Title: Flash Freeze Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A vigorous cold front will make temperatures drop rapidly Tuesday. The significant decrease of temperatures will operate from west to east and is expected early Tuesday morning for areas of Northwestern Quebec. For the remaining areas, this drop of temperatures will occur during the day Tuesday. Rain or wet snow precipitation that will accompany the passage of the front will contribute to making the roads and walkways slippery. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Flash freeze warnings are issued when a rapid drop in temperature is expected, that can cause water from rain or melted snow on streets and sidewalks to quickly freeze. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T18:50:22-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Total rainfall: 40 to 80 mm, with the highest amounts falling over the higher terrain of the Long Range Mountains and inland of the Southwest Coast. Maximum wind gusts: southerly at 80 to 100 km/h, with the highest gusts along the coast. Locations: Gros Morne, Cornerbrook, Bay St. George, Port aux Basques and Burgeo - Ramea. Time span: Monday night through Wednesday. Remarks: Rain will begin Monday night then become heavy, at times, Tuesday with strong southerly winds. The wind and rain will become less intense Tuesday night before transitioning to flurries on Wednesday. In addition, the strong winds and heavy rainfall will result in snowmelt over higher elevation which may increase the potential for localized flooding. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills continues this morning. Under mainly clear skies, wind chill values are once again expected to return to the minus 45 to minus 50 range across portions of northern Saskatchewan Monday overnight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Temperatures in the minus thirties combined with northwest winds of 15 km/h will result in extreme wind chills near the warning threshold of -45 over far northern Manitoba this morning. Conditions should moderate slightly during the afternoon, but extreme wind chills will likely return Monday night and persist into Tuesday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Highest wind gusts: near 100 km/h Location: Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia Timeframe: overnight tonight and Tuesday morning Remarks: Strong southerly winds will develop tonight with gusts reaching 100 km/h before morning along the South Shore. These strong wind will move up the coast toward Halifax and the Eastern Shore in the early morning hours on Tuesday, and reach the Atlantic Coast of Cape Breton mid morning. Winds will begin to diminish along the South Shore on Tuesday morning and by Tuesday afternoon over Cape Breton. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-10T06:28:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-09T14:28:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1686322047.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Total Rainfall: 50 to 75 mm Locations: Tri-county region Timeframe: This afternoon, tonight, and Tuesday morning Remarks: Rain, heavy at times, will begin this afternoon and continue through the night into Tuesday morning. The rain will then taper to scattered showers and drizzle. Rain is likely to become steady again Tuesday night before a changeover to snow on Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-10T00:37:23-00:00

Area: Digby County, Shelburne County, Yarmouth County

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lasting blizzard conditions with potentially damaging winds and persistent visibility near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. A strong arctic ridge of high pressure will set up over the Northwest Territories today. With low pressure over Alaska, strong winds with blowing snow are expected for northern sections of the Dempster. Near the Richardson Mountains winds will increase to 90 km/h gusting to 110 tonight resulting in blizzard conditions. Blizzard conditions are forecast to last through Wednesday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Road closures are likely. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-10T04:40:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-09T12:41:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2307040570.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A disturbance tracking through western Hudson Strait will bring increasing easterly winds into the Pangnirtung region this morning. Easterly winds of 70 gusting to 90 km/h are expected to develop later this morning and last through much of the afternoon. These strong winds will produce reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds are expected to diminish this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-10T00:26:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-09T08:27:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2329658281.2019
Area: Pangnirtung
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure system over northern Hudson Bay continues to produce strong north winds gusting to 75 km/h creating blizzard conditions with near zero visibilities in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions are expected to persist through Tuesday morning with gradual improvement Tuesday afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-10T01:29:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-09T09:30:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3546141550.2019
Area: Naujaat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 30 to 65 mm. Highest amounts expected near the Fundy Coast. Locations: Central and Southern New Brunswick Time frame: This afternoon, tonight, and Tuesday morning Remarks: Rain, heavy at times will move into New Brunswick this afternoon and persist into the morning hours on Tuesday. This rain will be accompanied by mild temperatures and will lead to significant melting and run-off in areas with an existing snow pack. Strong gusty southwesterly winds are also expected tonight with gusts reaching 80 km/h. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-10T00:37:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-09T08:38:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0512329783.2019
